result.title: Objective
result.description: To provide farmers with the necessary incentives, capabilities and supporting institutional framework to conserve agro-biodiversity within the farming systems of Lao PDR

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Area under improved management for conservation of agro-biodiversity directly and indirectly influenced by the ABP project
[Revised]

actual.comment:
300 ha (accumulated)
Work done in close collaboration with the TABI project. A digital satellite map (SPOT 6, Archive Imagery, 2,900 km2) have been purchased facilitating the verification of draft village land use plans including allocation of biodiversity important areas. Expected to be approved by local authorities during the 3rd quarter of 2015. Other started-up biodiversity conservation activities include forest areas for wild tea and melientha trees (used as vegetables). The forests in these areas have been surveyed for wild tea and maps and reports are being prepared as basis for the district authorities to regulate as conservation areas, The regulations together with the ongoing domestication efforts are expected to significantly reduce the unsustainable harvests in the forest.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Number of agro-biodiversity taxonomic groups with improved status in the two pilot districts
[New]

actual.comment:
0
The project has drawn attention to Oyster Mushrooms, Wild tea, Melientha and wild mushrooms and these groups are expected gained special status during the latter part of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
GEF SP-2 Tracking Tool Score for policy and regulatory frameworks
[New]

target.comment: 5 out of 5 for agriculture, fisheries and forestry sectors

actual.comment:
General:
For the first time biodiversity has repeatedly been mentioned in the 8th. Socio-Economic Development Plan e.g. output 1 of outcome 3 where biodiversity is stressed as an important element of sustainable natural resource management, managed by the farmers. The new research strategy of the National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute states agro-biodiversity a one of the three objectives. Further, the agro-biodiversity is increasingly discussed in Sector Working Group Meetings and the government encourage local government to consider to link agro-biodiversity into their sector activities
As per tracking tools the project has achieved score 2 of 6, and will increase emphasis on implementation, enforcement and monitoring in the remaining period. The score for these three sectors (Agriculture, Forestry, Fishery) is increased from 0 to 2 as biodiversity considerations are mentioned in sector policy and specific legislation. Detailed explanations are given below.
- Agriculture 2: The Draft Agricultural Development Strategy (ADS), 2020 Short-medium term: Promote environmental friendly market-integrated ANR growth. Long-term: Ensure agricultural and forestry practices are ecologically sustainable, maintain production potential and quality of agricultural biodiversity. Further, the new Upland Development Strategy (2015-20) includes: Biodiversity conserved for eco-tourism as one of four objectives.
- Forestry Sector 2: The draft Agriculture Development Strategy stresses: Biodiversity conserved for eco-tourism and to protect and domesticate NTFPs and to protect forests.
Fishery Sector: 2 - Fish Biodiversity is mentioned in the NBSAP and PBSAP as part of agro-biodiversity and it is agreed and acknowledged by Lao Government. The government is establishing fish conservation zones in rivers as stipulated in the Fisheries Law and underpins the ongoing aquatic biodiversity conservation efforts.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: National policy and institutional frameworks for sustainable use, and in-situ conservation of biodiversity in agro-ecosystems

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of new national plans, policies, laws, and guidelines with agro-biodiversity

baseline.comment:
Land use policies and legal instruments do not include focus on biodiversity (especially agro biodiversity).
Agriculture Law does not incorporate emphasis on biodiversity, including agro-biodiversity.
Integration of biodiversity related criteria into ESIA guidelines are poor.

actual.comment:
4 (accumulated)
Several rounds of comments have been provided the recently approved Upland Develop Strategy (added a biodiversity objective), as well as its Implementation Plan.
Further, comments have been provided to the National Nutrition Strategy and the Environment Strategy 2020. As a result both none of them have included agro-biodiversity issues. Both need formal approval.
ABP project is assisting the government to preparing the second National Agrobiodiversity Programme with expected Government approval during the latter part of 2015.
Finally, the project will provide inputs to the 5th National Report to CBD and is in the process of starting-up support to preparation of the Luang Prabang Provincial Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Number of national workshops with biodiversity content
[Indicator deleted after MTR and consideration by project board]

baseline.comment: Emphasis on agro-biodiversity in BD strategy and action plan is weak

target.comment: 10 workshops

actual.comment: Indicator deleted

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Number of yearly agro-biodiversity inter-sectoral coordination meetings
[Indicator deleted after MTR and consideration by project board]

baseline.comment: Currently, there is no formal coordination mechanism for agro-biodiversity conservation

target.comment: 2 yearly meetings (see below)

actual.comment: Indicator deleted

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Number GOL officers actively participating in meetings and training on agro-biodiversity
[Revised]

baseline.comment: Institutional and staff capacities of MAF/GOL to mainstream biodiversity into agriculture and land use policies are low.

target.comment: 500 officers

actual.comment:
490 (accumulated)
One launching workshop (25p) on the Provincial Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan (PBSAP) was organized for Xieng Khouang Province (August) and one PBSAP planning meetings (30p) was held (October) in Luang Prabang Province.
Further, two National Agro-biodiversity Programme formulation feed-back meetings (20 p) have been held in March. At these meetings participants were actively discussing (agro) biodiversity issues.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Number of tools (FFS, info & awareness materials) developed to support and enhance incorporation of agro-biodiversity into national and institutional frameworks issues are discussed
[Revised]

baseline.comment: Existing tools such as training, extension, communication and mapping are not adequately used for wider stakeholder awareness or mainstream biodiversity into their work

target.comment: 6 tools

actual.comment:
Achieved, 6 tools.
Tool no 6: General awareness and information material.
As part of a comprehensive awareness and communication strategy and implementation plan (December), the project has initiated a number of general awareness and information material, including a) project brochure (English and Lao, 250 copies each), prepared a stand for the World Food Day (October) on agrobiodiversity issues, prepared one success story (aquatic organism) and project brief (English) on wild mushrooms (English), conducted one press conference in connection with the International Day on Biodiversity, environment day (summary uploaded on YouTube), and prepared one video on TOT-participants reaction on 8-week training (in Lao with English sub-title).

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description:
Number of strategic inputs to the policy and legislative process produced by the inter-sectoral working group, as demonstrated through policy papers or other forms of strategic inputs to the development of policies such as the NABP-II
[New]

actual.comment:
0
Strategic input to the NABP is expected during the second half of 2015.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Capacities and incentives to mainstream biodiversity, especially agro-biodiversity, at the Provincial, District and community levels

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of farmers adopting skills and techniques promoted through FFS and farmer field days

baseline.comment:
Existing strategies and capacity building for 2 target provinces agriculture land use do not incorporate biodiversity conservation.
Existing training and extension do not incorporate agro-biodiversity conservation issues .

target.comment: 1,000 farmers

actual.comment:
562 farmers (accumulated)
- 8 leader farmers of a total of 37 trainees completed TOT on Rice and Agrobiodiversity (Jul-Apr) with topics related to facilitation skills and disseminating technical knowledge at village based Farmer Field Schools (FFS).
- 105 rice farmers as members of FFS and as integral part of the TOT.
- 22 additional Farmers participating in Farmer Field Days (FFDs), (as part of TOT and not including farmers mentioned above). The FFD demonstrates ABD issues practiced during the Farmer Field Schools (FFS) and Training of Trainers. In this way the results are disseminated to the local community, including neighbouring farmers, pupils, and government officers. The trained trainers started-up FFS in 2014-2015 vegetable season and 2015 rice season.
- 255 vegetable farmer graduates from intensive FFS/Integrated Pest Management (IPM) including usage of local herb extracts as bio-insecticides.
- 66 Farmers at Farmer Field Days (Vegetable FFS).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of Technical Service Centers in cluster villages with agro-biodiversity conservation and sustainable use activities

baseline.comment: Existing strategies and capacity building for 2 target provinces; agriculture land use do not incorporate biodiversity.

target.comment: 4 TSCs

actual.comment:
6
A total of 6 Technical Service Centers staff in Nambor, Donkham, Phongthong, Ladngai, Phengthong, and Phinglounag are actively participating in field activities (with delegated implementation responsibilities) in conjunction other tasks given by district authorities)

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Number of cluster villages with approved pFLUP plans adapted and beginning implementation
[Revised]

baseline.comment: Existing area with participatory land use plans and participatory are low and do not include agro-biodiversity conservation.

target.comment: 8 cluster villages

actual.comment:
0
Verification of the pFLUP is ongoing for a full and comprehensive Village Forest and Land Use Management Plan for Phoukout and Phonexai districts District (7 clusters) is expected to be approved during the second half of 2015, whereas important follow-up will take place in 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of districts with in-situ agro-biodiversity conservation plans

baseline.comment: Currently there is no formal allocation of land for in-situ conservation of agro-biodiversity .

target.comment: 8 districts

actual.comment:
2
Phonexay and Phoukhout districts through implementation of project agrobiodiversity activities

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
Number of male and female farmers graduated from FFS (at least 50% females)
[Revised]

baseline.comment: Existing training and extension do not incorporate agro-biodiversity conservation issues

target.comment:
1,000 pp
50% of women targeted

actual.comment:
360 farmers - 76% females (accumulated)
- 105 rice farmers (70% females) as members of FFS (as integral part of the TOT).
- 255 vegetable farmer graduates (81% females) from intensive FFS/Integrated Pest Management (IPM) including usage of local herb extracts as bio-insecticides, which is an example of use of local biodiversity.
The trained trainers will continue FFS/IPM in 2015/16.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description:
Number of value added agro-biodiversity products promoted and marketed for local or international markets
[Revised]

baseline.comment: existing market for agro-biodiversity and biodiversity friendly products are ineffective.

target.comment: 8 products

actual.comment:
1
The project has assisted the four group of villagers with market information, labels for sale bags (each village with specific logo), and a village sign board on oyster mushrooms.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description:
Number of private-public sector agro-biodiversity agreements
[Indicator deleted after MTR and consideration by project board and RTA]

baseline.comment: Private and public sectors involvement and incentives for biodiversity conservation are extremely limited .

actual.comment: Indicator deleted

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description:
Number of FFS graduates with increased understanding and knowledge of farming practices that are supportive of agro-biodiversity
[New]

target.comment: 2 per FFS

actual.comment:
8 per FFS
(Assessed by CTA and local extension officers)

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description:
Number of cluster villages with at least two demonstrated actions or activities representing implementation of pLUPS, or with actions covering at least 10% of the area under the pFLUP
[New]

actual.comment: No pFLUPs yet finalized

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description:
Number of publications disseminated analyzing economic forces and incentives influencing the status of at least one sub-group of Agro-biodiversity in NABP-II
[New]

indicator.description:
Number of strategic recommendations from the Agro-biodiversity Steering committee

Number of MAF organized cross project meetings

result.title: Objective
result.description: Food insecurity resulting from climate change in Lao PDR minimized and vulnerability of farmers to extreme flooding and drought events reduced.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Availability of a framework for climate change resilient agriculture in Lao PDR

baseline.comment: Climate risk considerations are not integrated into major agricultural sector policies (including the National Agricultural Strategy to 2020); institutional, organizational and individual capacities to understand the link between climate change and future food security need to be strengthened.

target.comment: By the end of the Project a framework for CC resilient agriculture is available, and being used by the GoL in actively planning for widespread introduction of adaptation measures.

actual.comment:
By mid-2015 the institutional framework for climate resilient agriculture has been strengthened by a number of appropriate technology innovations and on-ground adaptation practice introduced by IRAS and some other projects that replicate the IRAS approach in one way or another. As a result of these, climate resilience has gained a much higher profile in the preparation of the new National Socio-Economic Development Plan / SEDP 8 (2016-2020), the UNDP round-table-process, as well as in the country strategy papers of donors and international agencies.
In general, the Lao framework for climate resilience consists of the National Steering Committee for the environment, chaired by the Deputy Prime Minister, vice-chairmanship and standing chairpersons is the Minister of MONRE, again vice-chaired by the Minister of MAF.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Percentage of households in pilot districts (Savannakhet and Xayaboury province) actively implementing climate change adaptation measures introduced by the project

baseline.comment: Current agricultural practices among subsistence farmers are based on historical climatic conditions and trends and are unsuited to increase flooding and drought conditions that are becoming increasingly frequent in Lao PDR.

target.comment: By the end of the project 6 Training and Agricultural Adaptation Modules (CCTAMs) have been extended to 75% of target households in 2 pilot districts (Savannakhet province, Xayaboury province)

actual.comment: Based on the figures from the Climate Change Training and Adaptation Module (CCTAM) courses and their introduction and dispersion in the IRAS target districts, around 27,000 persons (82%) of the farmers in target areas have been brought into the extension process; this exceeds the indicator target. Indirect beneficiaries are around 98,000 persons that can be counted as coming in touch with the extension process through the initial farmer target groups.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Proportion and value (yield) of agricultural assets with increased resilience to climate change as a result of adaptation measures implemented by this project

baseline.comment: Currently the yield of agricultural land is being affected by climate change related factors leading to reductions in productivity.

target.comment: By the end of the project interventions on the ground increase agricultural productivity on Climate Change affected land by 25%

actual.comment: In average, the improved rice seed increased seasonal profits by 78% and 3% under rain-fed and irrigated conditions, respectively, compared to the varieties in use before. Profits from various livestock increased average household incomes up to 70% depending on the species of livestock. Self-distribution by farmer to farmer of TDK seed spread through 60 % of the total low land rice fields of 7,941 ha. TDK 1/1 is flood tolerant and can survive less than 20 days of flooding, while TDK 8 and TDK 11 are drought tolerant and can survive 10-15 days of drought. Rice yield increased with an average yield of 4 t/ha, compared to the project baseline of 2.7 t/ha in 2011. The yield in the flood areas of Champhone district increased more than in the drought areas of Outhoumphone and Paklay districts. Around 3,500 kg of varieties were produced, the average price of vegetables is 12,000 k/kg, and the income generation for this is around 42,000,000 K. 240 native ducks and 500 chicken, 400 Egypt chicken, 60 domestic piglets, 70 goats and 36 cows were provided for 100 farmer households in flood and drought areas. Total cost for all livestock provided is 220,500,000K. Some livestock such chicken and ducks are raised for eating and only some have been sold for 25,000-30,000 K/kg. Until 2015 the stock has increased by 17 small cattle and 45 small goats. Native frogs, fishes such as papak, panine, panai, carp, catfish and other were demonstrated in ponds, plastic ponds, cages and in rice fields of 99 farmer households in 4 target districts, especially linked to water management activities. The total of fish and frog seedling provided are 43,300 and 5,180 heads, respectively. More than 300,000 fingerlings were produced for farmers in Phieng district. The yield of 5,400 catfish is around 432 kg and the yield of 2,100 frogs is around 285 kg. The price of catfish is around 18,000 k/kg, while for frog is around 25,000 k/kg.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Increased knowledge and understanding of climate variability and climate induced threats on agricultural production, food security and vulnerability, in Lao PDR

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Cover: Number and type of stakeholders served by expanded climate and vulnerability information and knowledge base related to agriculture and food security

baseline.comment: Basic regional climate change information has been compiled in the NAPA Lao PDR. However this information has not been sufficiently downscaled or applied to the agricultural sector. Vulnerability information is scattered across public and private sector entities, government departments and development agencies.

target.comment: All stakeholders identified during PPG and inception phases have access to an efficiently organized and up to date knowledge and information network for climate change impacts on agriculture and food security.

actual.comment: Stakeholders in PPG: 39 groups: departments, projects on national, provincial, district level - main groups are district authorities, provincial authorities and farmers. They all received information on impacts of climate change and adaptation knowledge from the 7 Climate Change Training and Adaptation Modules / CCTAMs (crop/agro-forestry, fishery/aquaculture, livestock, vegetables/fruit tree, off-farm income generation, safeguarding land and water management), awareness creation in schools and pagodas, the disaster management manual, and through land use maps. New stakeholders: #10 additional government agencies (natural resources and environment division, health division, planning and investment division, disaster management office, land management office, womens union office, TSC, DGRV, AFC, Embassy of Israel in Hanoi) Some of them are now regularly receiving climate information. Beside these, other authorities were reached through the Local Integration Platform (LIP) Committees and many international organizations in numerous meetings throughout the implementation phase. GIS training courses were organized for staff of NAFRI, IRAS, DAEC, DDMCC, NDMO and DLPD. NAFRI IT is structuring the project website and the options for offering the content to the public, there is a large number of clicks into the website (>673,400 as end of June 2015). All news/information from progress of main activities are uploaded to 3 main websites (NAFRI/IRAS, UNDP Laos and UNDP ALM). Main contents uploaded to the website are reports of workshop/meetings, trainings, awareness raising, and exchange visits. After CCTAMs development (crop/agro-forestry, fishery/aquaculture, livestock, vegetables/fruit tree, off-farm and safeguarding land) completed, pretests and TOTs on CCTAMs were organized for PAFO, DAFO and TSC staffs in 4 target districts, 257 persons (35 females) attended. TOTs on disaster risk management were organized for local authorities, 528 villagers of 22 target villages have trained and practiced on disaster risk reduction planning. Daily dissemination of climate relevant news and technical information took place through email circular to 35 agriculture professionals directly working in the project.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Impact: Numbers of national and provincial level stakeholders using improved climate and vulnerability information in formulation of climate resilient policies and plans.

baseline.comment: Information is currently not in a form that can be used by national stakeholders in a user-friendly and policy-relevant manner. It is not available in any form to sub-national authorities and key specialists (such as local planners and extension workers) responsible for working with farmers directly.

target.comment: By the end of the project 60% of identified national and provincial government stakeholders are using the knowledge base for sector planning: strategies, long-term plans, annual plans and budgets, project work plans

actual.comment: Nearly 100% of all stakeholders identified in the PPG and inception phase were reached and climate resilience communication or working relationships were established. Nearly 100% of all new stakeholders were also reached. 80 people (11 females) of PDMC and DDMC were trained on community based disaster risk management using the training manual developed under the project. Some climate relevant information from other countries is disseminated by weAdapt, APAN, Eldis . >30 Government agencies were engaged in review and consultation of 5 policies, strategies and draft law (Agriculture Law, National Land Policy, Strategy for Agriculture Development 2011-2020, Upland Development Strategy for Agriculture and Rural Development 2015-2020, Policy Development and Recommendation in the Agriculture sector related to Climate Change Adaptation in Lao PDR). 34 land use plans which included flood and drought zones in all target villages were completed and dissemination workshops for related subnational parties were organized at NAFRI, IRAS: DLPD, PAFO, DAFO, Land Management Office (LMO), Heads of villages; 130 persons attended. An information workshop on cooperatives and climate change was organized together with DGRV35 persons (8 females) participated.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Sustainability: Resources available to maintain knowledge base after end of the project

baseline.comment: There is no national budget allocation for establishing and maintaining an appropriate knowledge network for climate change information.

target.comment: By the end of the project 50% of cost for operation and maintenance of the knowledge base and information network are included in the sectoral budget allocation for agriculture

actual.comment: Viewing NAFRI as a standalone agency and science compound, the cost for maintaining the IRAS knowledge base are low, between $100 to $200 per year. This amount can be fully collected on shared basis by the organizations on the NAFRI compound utilizing the service. Therefore the regular cost for operation and maintenance can be covered by 100% through the existing arrangements. Inspired by IRAS, a Climate Change Adaptation Research and Coordination Office (CACO) has been established at NAFRI, awaiting formal approval by MAF. In a wider context, and for the national level, all contributions from the Lao government are in-kind: human resources, offices, administration, services. 5 NAFRI staff are working part-time with IRAS, the calculated amount for all GoL inputs and services in IRAS are security, offices, equipment, air conditioning, meeting rooms, internet services, and is estimated a value of $400,000 for the whole project duration. The annual cost to maintain the IRAS knowledge base at NAFRI is around 800,000-1,500,000 Kip.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Capacities of sectoral planners and agricultural producers strengthened to understand and address climate change - related risks and opportunities for local food production and socio-economic conditions

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 2.1. Cover: Number of targeted institutions (agriculture, water management, food security, early warning, poverty alleviation, etc) with increased capacity to reduce risks of and respond to climate variability.

baseline.comment: Capacity gaps at the national and provincial level to access, understand, interpret and apply climate risk information to promote climate resilient agricultural planning and investment decisions are prominent.

target.comment: By the end of the project at least 4 planners from at least 6 sectors / sub-sectors relevant to agriculture, food security and CC are able to effectively apply climate risk information in annual and multi- year planning exercises and have applied these skills to the review and revision of existing sector / sub-sector strategies.

actual.comment: The target was met with sectoral planners in 6 MAF entities (Department of Irrigation, Department of Agriculture, Department of Agriculture Extension and Cooperation, Department of Livestock and Fisheries, Department of Agriculture Land Development) and from different research entities under NAFRI having been working with IRAS on GIS related activities with focus on drought and flood, the production of maps, plans, scenarios. From MONRE, 2 entities (Department of Land Planning and Development and Department of Disaster Management and Climate Change) have been included.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2.2. Impact: Number of targeted agricultural officers, extension workers, farmer cooperatives and TSC (Technical Service Center) members in target districts have an advanced understanding of key climate change risk and impacts on agricultural production and socio-economic conditions.

baseline.comment: At the district and village level, farmer cooperatives and Disaster Management Committees lack financial resources and knowledge for resilience decision making in the face of dynamic hydro-meteorological hazards. Poverty reduction strategies and land use planning in Lao PDR give limited consideration to climate variability and change.

target.comment: By the end of the project 75% of DAFO, DDMC, TSC staff in target districts have been trained in applying climate risk information and are applying this acquired knowledge in the planning and implementation of their activities.

actual.comment: The total number of staff in the 4 target DAFOs, TSCs and DDMCs is 337 persons. Most all of them were trained (>80%) in matters related to basic climate change science and community-based adaptation options in the agriculture sector. Application of new knowledge through regular participation in field activities of IRAS: 32 staff of MAF, PAFO, DAFO (administrative level), 185 staff (57 women) of DAEC, 39 staff from Technical Service Centers, DDMCC 38 (20 women), NDMO 8 (3 women), DLPD 86 (21 women), 443 HH in 7 villages of Champhon (in water user groups). 7 CCTAMs (crop/agro-forestry, fishery/aquaculture, livestock, vegetables/fruit tree, off-farm, safeguarding land and water management) were conducted and pretested and TOTs were organized for local authorities, especially DAFO and TSC staff. CBDRM training manual completed, TOTs were organized for local authorities especially DDMCs. Study tours, cross-exchange visits to learn and share knowledge/experience on climate change and agriculture were organized with different government agencies: i) Study tour on Disaster Risk Management to Thailand organized with 29 people from difference agencies to explore the good practice and share real experiences on DRM implementation; ii) study tour on Climate Change Adaptation Models to Vietnam was organized with 23 people to share experiences of project implementation with climate change project at Hue University of Agriculture and Forestry. Cross-exchange visit to Cambodia organized with 23 people to exchange practical experiences on community-based agriculture adaptation practice.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Community-based adaptive agricultural practices and off-farm opportunities demonstrated and promoted within suitable agro-ecological systems

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 3.1. Cover: Number and type of climate risk-reducing farmer level practices identified and trialed to support adaptation of livelihoods and/or resource management.

baseline.comment: Agricultural practices, extension services and demonstration sites have not yet been adapted to take climate change risks into account. For example changes in tributary peak flows, changing rainfall intensities and prolonged dry spells are not considered.

target.comment: By the end of the project at least 100 practical field-based adaptation interventions (food security, water management, flood and drought control) are trialed in the 4 pilot districts according to accepted technical standards

actual.comment:
A total of 103 field based practical interventions (according to concept notes that may have included different villages in one activity, or different activities in one village) were implemented, plus 84 workshops, training and similar in the field. This interventions addressed the following issues:
- Food Security: 34 interventions
- Water management: 28 interventions.
- Flood control: 17 interventions
- Drought control: 24 interventions
- Training/workshops: 84
- The total # of beneficiaries from these activities is 15,112 people (5,127 females), including: 3,444 GoL officers (941 females) and 11,668 farmers (4,186 females).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 3.2. Cover: % or targeted farming households aware of predicted adverse impacts of climate change and implementing new adaptive practices for agro-ecosystem and landscape management.

baseline.comment: There is a general lack of awareness about community-based approaches to address climate change risks. As there is consistently less diversification in products, smallholder farmers are generally not able to adapt to dynamic changes in the climatic variables that influence their land, water source, crop, health and yield.

target.comment: By the end of the project 75% of farming households in 4 pilot districts (2 provinces), equivalent to 13,500 households, have had access to extension services based on 6 Climate Change Training and Agriculture Adaptation Modules (climate resilient cropping, livestock, fisheries and forestry practices, water management etc.)

actual.comment: 27,179 people (around 5436 HH) constituting 82% of the target have been reached by 18 government extension officers supervising 131 field interventions related to the Climate Change Training and Adaptation Modules (CCTAM). Figures segregated by district are Phieng district: 21%, Paklay distict: 21%, Outhoumphone district: 28%, Champhone district: 30%. These 82 % include 974 households that were reached by extension activities through livestock training and off-farm activities (e.g. basket making). Figures segregated by district: Phieng: 29%; Paklay district: 39%; Outhoumphone district: 13%; Champhone district: 19%. The 82% mark also includes 1,528 households that benefited from agro-extension (fishery/aquaculture, livestock, fruit/vegetable) associated with water management. Figures per district are: Phieng district: 33%; Paklay district: 36%; Outhoumphone district:12%; Champhone district: 19%.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3.3. Impact: Improvement in farmer yields and water availability due to adaptation measures trialed in more than 50% of targeted communities.

baseline.comment: The majority of farmers rely on subsistence rain-fed rice farming for their daily staple and sale, and on wild meat and aquatic resources for their source of animal protein.

target.comment: By the end of the project there is a 25% improvement in farmer yields resulting from adaptation measures trialed in target communities in 4 pilot districts

actual.comment:
Income generation and farming system diversification:
For rice, as the main crop, the average yield increased from 2.75 t/ha to 4.5 t/ha (wet season 2014). This reflects an increase of 63% increase over 111 ha.
Goats: 70 goats were supported by IRAS, the herd grew by 45 goats, and total # of goats is now 115 heads (+ 64%).
Cattle: 36 cows were supported by IRAS, the herd grew 17 cows, and total # of cows now is 53 heads (+ 47%).
Aquaculture: 55 cages for fish raising in ponds, 31 cages for catfish raising in plastic pond sand 12 cages for frog raising. According to the model households, the yields are around 70kg/cage, 7-8 heads/kg, the price is 18,000k/kg ($2.5/kg = $175/cage).
Aquaculture demonstration (weight reflects the value):
377,000 of fingerlings (catfish) were produced with the new hatcheries supported by IRAS. Most of these fingerlings were raised in the Phieng TSC, some were provided to farmers in the target villages.
5,400 catfishes were provided to 1 farmer household for raising in cages for demonstration purposes, the weight of the fish is around 432 kg. 6,000 catfish provided to 2 farmer households for raising in ponds for demonstration purposes, the weight of the fish is around 450 kg.
2,500 small frogs were provided to 4 farmer households for raising in cages, the weight of frogs is around 285kg.
10,000 tilapia provided for 3 farmer households to raise in cages, the weight of fish is around 2,000 kg
4,000 tilapia provided for 2 farmer households for raising in ponds, the weight of fish is around 870 kg.
4,000 tilapia provided to one farmer household for raising in rice fields, the weight of fish is around 1,000 kg.
240 egg ducks were provided for 20 farmer households, around 50 dead, around 1800 eggs gained, 99 small ducks increased (+ 26%).
500 chickens provided for 20 farmer households, around half died, 230 eggs gained and 243 small chicken increased (+/- 0%).
All prices (K/kg) at local markets are in favour of products produced under IRAS: sticky rice 7,000K, steamed rice 10,000 K, duck 25,000-30,000 K, chicken 30,000- 35,000 K, fish 25.000 K, pig (live) 22.000 K, beef 80.000 K, vegetables 8000k/kg.
Potable water in flood and drought areas:
542 big jars provided to farmers in 5 villages, 24,390 m3/month or 97,560 m3/season of water can be stored which saves money from buying potable water of around 1,626,000,000 K or around 203,000 USD for a season.
576 well tubes were provided to farmers in 2 villages, 6,720 m3/month or 26,880 m3/season of water can stored which saves money from buying potable water of around 448,000,000 K or around 56,000 USD for a season.
Water management / flood and drought control
Most water collected in the ponds is used for fish raising and some are utilizing it for vegetable and fruit tree planting.
15 reservoirs were constructed for small farmer user groups with a capacity between 80-7500 m3.
1 Dam (Huay Khee) reconstruction for large group of households (more than 150 families) with a capacity of 39,600 m3.
1 small concrete weir for water storing in the dry season was constructed with a capacity of 60,000 m3.
11 Ponds for fish raising and vegetables planting were constructed with a capacity of f 1,350-4500 m3.
6 water storage station for primary schools constructed with a capacity of around 38 m3.
6 embankments for flood protection were constructed with average size of 200m in length, 2m in width and 1.45m in height.
Total cost of physical works is around 169,135 USD.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Adaptation Monitoring and Learning as a long-term process

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 4.1. Replicability: Number of lessons learned codified in a specific KM facility such as the Adaptation Knowledge Platform for South East Asia or the global Adaptation Learning Mechanism.

baseline.comment: The current knowledge about successful and unsuccessful climate risk management approaches in the agricultural sector in Lao PDR is not systematically captured and analyzed.

target.comment: A project internal M+E system covering all components and all project locations systematically provides quantitative and qualitative data and information on coded lessons learned and a website has been established linked to wider dissemination through regional and global networks (ALM, Wiki-adapt, Eldis and the Asia Knowledge Platform)

actual.comment: The IRAS website at NAFRI was established in 2012 after IRAS official starting in mid-May 2011. Since then, the website recorded a total of 705,100 views from around the world. The UNDP ALM website is regularly provided with new materials from the project and will contain all knowledge products by end-of-project in October 2015. In general, IRAS uses and sporadically interacts with 6 different websites dedicated to climate knowledge management and practice. 4 You-Tube videos, including from DDMCC, were uploaded to the NAFRI/IRAS website and 5 more videos will uploaded before October 15.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 4.2. Replicability: Number and type of relevant networks or communities through which lessons learned are disseminated to enable replication.

baseline.comment: As there is presently no knowledge management mechanism that would allow the systematic capturing and dissemination of lessons learned from different climate change adaptation projects, there is no way for Government, provincial and district authorities, and sector planners to learn from the lessons learned or to scale up successful activities.

target.comment: By the end of the project 2 regional conferences on CC+AA are organized by NAFRI for GMS member states (in collaboration with partner organizations) for SE ASIA (UNEP, SID, SEI, UNDP, ADB)

actual.comment: One NAFRI conference in April 2014 covered climate change relevant topics; papers were shared with an audience of more than 70 people. The 1st NAFRI/IRAS CCA Conference was organized in June 2014. Content: Knowledge management and policies for field adaptation (177 participants). According to the evaluation, 150 participants rated 100% of the lectures satisfactorily. The 2nd IRAS/NAFRI CCA Conference was organized on 22-23 July 2015. Content: agro-ecology and climate adaptation in agriculture (172 participants (48 females) from Lao PDR, Thailand and other regional experts, and from different agencies in Laos. According to the evaluation, 145 people rated 90% of the lectures as satisfactory. A study tour on disaster management in Thailand was undertaken. Main content: the study tour team visited the province and district authorities who are in charge of disaster management to share experiences and good practices on disaster preparedness and response to emergency. A study tour was undertaken to the climate change model center for climate change studies in central Vietnam. The study tour visited the adaptation model areas of 3 provinces (Quang Binh, Quang Tri and Hue) of Vietnam. A Cambodia CCA team (34 people) visited IRAS on 20-25 April 2014 to share knowledge and experience on CC and agriculture. A cross-exchange visit with Cambodia was organized with participants from different agencies, consisting of 23 persons (7 females) on 15-21 February 2015. A Bangladesh CCA delegation visited IRAS project on 22-24 June 2015 with 12 people (2 females). Two staff from IRAS attended the international conference on climate change (COP 20), in Lima, Peru, 2014. This attendance helped to bring issues like INDC, climate finance, loss and damage into the discussion among Lao partners, donors, GoL agencies, and led to further support by UNDP.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of environmental economic evidence (financial analysis, economic studies, and policy briefs) produced and disseminated to support sustainable and equitable investments. 2. Number of key organizations (involved in decision making processes) participating in identification of research topics and at dissemination workshops. 3. Existence of Cross-sectoral collaboration mechanism to guide targeted environmental economics research. 4. Existence of training module and a manual on environmental economics introduced in MPI Economics and Planning Training Centre curricula and other academic/training institutes.

baseline.comment: 1. Few environmental economic report (Economic Valuation of Ecosystem Services and Poverty Alleviation) available to support sustainable and equitable investments. 2. Only a few key organisations (involved in decision making) are involved in identifying research topics or represented in NERI dissemination workshops. 3. Very few, if any, operational cross-sectoral collaboration mechanisms in environmental economics. 4. 0

target.comment: 1. 1 - Economic evidence produced and disseminated to technical groups and policy makers by competing one environmental economic research topics identified with corresponding literature reviews, meta-analysis, methodology, data sets collected and reports prepared on each research topic - including two policy briefs. Two mini grants approved with corresponding mini research reports. 2. 3 (MPI and NA and MoNRE) 3. Cross-sectoral collaboration mechanism (National Experts Group and Advisory Board) formulated and engaged in environmental economic research. 4. First draft of environmental economics training manual developed.

actual.comment: 1. Five Researches finalized which two of five were published: (I) Economic Valuation of Ecosystem Services and Poverty Alleviation: a Case Study on Land Use in Oudomxay Province; (ii) rubber concession in Lao PDR an impact assessment for monitoring indicators; (iii) Final draft contract farming study report; (iv) final draft soil quality analysis report for the rubber plantation; (v) final draft gender role in the contract farming. 2. 3 3. Expert working group has been established to guide target environmental economic research. 4 team of expert working group are functioning and supporting the finalization of the contract farming study. 27 NERI staffs and expert members has strengthened research knowledge and skills through participating in the literature review training delivered by the PEI-NERI. 4. A Training module on the environmental economic valuation was completed and training was delivered to NERI staff, and to be published in early 2015.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Local administrative systems affecting the provision and maintenance of small scale rural infrastructure will be improved through participatory decision making that reflects the genuine needs of communities and natural systems vulnerable to climate risk.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Percentage change in number of district development plans including specific climate change adaptation actions in the target provinces and districts (AMAT 1.1.1)

baseline.comment: No CC adaptation actions are in place or budgeted for in district development plans in Sekong or Saravane.

target.comment: 50% of district development plans in the project area include at least 3 specific CCA actions by mid project and at least 5 CCA actions by end of project.

actual.comment: Four districts have already implemented their first climate resilient infrastructure based on the District Development Fund (DDF) mechanism (Lakhonpheng, Saravane, Kaleum and Lamarm districts), as pilots during late 2014 and 2015. All 12 districts have prioritised climate resilience projects into their district development plans for 2015. Through a consultation with all the districts in March 2015, 14 projects were prioritised for funding and implementation in 2015. All these 14 project sites were visited in June 2015 with the aim to assess their suitability for funding. Based on that assessment, it is anticipated that 11 out of 12 districts will implement one CCA project each in 2015. The DDF Guidelines have been revised with the aim to include climate resilience as a parameter for fund allocation to districts. The revised DDF Guidelines, including the fund allocation formula with the interim DVI, will be applied in full to guide the district fund allocation for the climate resilience grants from the 2016 fund allocation (3rd round of funds).

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Percentage change in the level of active local community participation in climate risk related planning in target provinces and districts.

baseline.comment: Although local communities in GPAR supported districts are aware of climate risks and taking part in planning decisions, there is no structured process in place for analysis and integration of these risks.

target.comment: 60% of District Development Support Committees in the target districts and provinces record specific climate related concerns emerging from community level annual planning consultations.

actual.comment: The District Development Support Committees of all 12 districts (100%) have been actively involved in the prioritising of projects for the next round of funding in 2015. 14 projects have been prioritised through district consultations (January, March 2015), and verified through site visits together with DDSC and DDST members (June 2015). Through this 'on-the-job' process, local capacity for inclusion of climate resilience into district planning processes has been built.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Capacities provided for local administrative institutions to integrate climate risks into participatory planning and financing of small scale rural water infrastructure provision.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1.1 Percentage change in the ability of local officials to apply methodologies to analyse climate risks and identify CC vulnerabilities in 12 districts

baseline.comment: Currently no climate risk analysis is carried out made at sub-national levels. Some macro level V&A work has been carried out (eg through the SNC process) but this analysis is not applicable for local level planning purposes

target.comment: 50% of sub-national officials are able to analyse climate risks for their districts on a macro level (V&A analysis) and are able to identify specific vulnerabilities and adaptation options at village level (CRVA).

actual.comment: Members of the DDST (5 members in 12 districts = 60 technical staff) have received on-the-job training in climate risk planning. They are expected to fully be able to analyse climate risks by Q1 of 2016 following the implementation of the CRVA. A Capacity Needs Assessment (CNA) for local departments at provincial and district levels was implemented from September-October 2014, and a capacity development plan was developed based on the CNA. Capacity development has been mainly done through 'on-the-job' activities and associated training events, such as identification and prioritisation of climate resilient infrastructure projects and ecosystem management plan development. However, the selection of a service provider to implement the CRVA has been a major challenge for the project. During the first bidding round in October-November 2014, only one company submitted a proposal, which substantially exceeded the budgetary limits of the project. The ToR for the CRVA was then revised and a second bidding round initiated in February 2015. A service provider was identified in reporting period so that the CRVA can be initiated in Quarter 3 of 2015, based on which the capacity for integrating climate resilience into local planning processes will be significantly improved from late 2015 and onwards

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 1.2 Procedures are in place to integrate climate change resilient advice and investment for small scale rural water infrastructure into district planning (YES/NO) (AMAT 1.1.1.1)

baseline.comment: No existing mechanism for climate resilient planning/ monitoring used for district development planning. There are no linkages made between the failure of water infrastructure and the inappropriate management of ecosystems.

target.comment: All 12 target districts are applying a climate resilient planning mechanism including project identification, site assessment, approval, execution and M&E.

actual.comment: With the revision of the DDF Guidelines and their expected approval by 3rd quarter of 2015, the procedures for integrating climate resilience into district planning and investments for rural water infrastructure, is well underway, however at the moment of reporting, no target districts apply a climate resilient planning mechanism. The selected CRVA service provider will include a significant element of capacity building of local authorities with the aim to facilitate this integration process. The CRVA will be implemented during 2nd half of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 1.3 Number of district development plans available, reflecting costs for adaptation in the water sector.

baseline.comment: CCA in the water sector currently not budgeted.

target.comment: All annual district investment plans include evidence of incremental CCA costings for water sector projects by year 4 and at least 4 provide this evidence by Year 2.

actual.comment: 11 out of 12 DDPs will include CCA projects, including their costing

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Incentives in place for small scale rural infrastructure to be protected and diversified against climate change induced risks (droughts, floods, erosion and landslides) benefitting at least 50,000 people in 12 districts of Sekong and Saravane

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 2.1 Number of districts routinely investing in climate resilient measures to improve village level water harvesting, storage and distribution systems.

baseline.comment: Existing village level water related infrastructure is poorly maintained and not designed to cope with increasing incidence of drought, flood or flash flood events.

target.comment: By the end of the project all target districts are investing at least 2 projects per year in village level climate resilient water harvesting, storage and distribution systems, which are informed by CRVA.

actual.comment: The revised DDF Guidelines includes a climate resilience criterion that provides the incentive for integrating climate resilience into the planning process in the short-term. In the long-term, the construction of climate-resilient projects will provide further incentives as the benefits of doing so are documented and experienced at the local level. The four pilot projects identified (2014) and implemented (2015) during the reporting period will be monitored closely within a results-based approach to assess impacts and demonstrate benefits from climate-resilient infrastructure. A baseline has been planned during the reporting period, which will be implemented in quarter 3 of 2015, followed by regular collection of data and information during the remaining period of the project. Similar processes for the 2nd round projects in 2015 will be implemented.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2.2 Number of people benefitting from investments in small-scale irrigation systems to increase their resilience against climate change risks. (AMAT 1.2.3)

baseline.comment:
Climate change resilience not built-into existing or new small-scale irrigation infrastructure.
Infrastructure poorly maintained and options often not appropriate to address the real situation.

target.comment: At least 50,000 people across 12 districts are benefitting from climate change resilient small-scale irrigation infrastructure, which has been informed by CRVA.

actual.comment: The first four pilot projects funded in 2014 and implemented within the reporting period benefit more that 4000 local villagers from the four districts of Kaleum and Lamarm in Sekong Province, and Lakhonpheng and Saravane in Saravane Province. The new projects for funding in 2015 (possibly 12 - to be confirmed), will benefit approximately 12,500 local people in 11 out of the 12 target districts (Tum La District did not manage to identify an eligible project this year)

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 2.3 District level fiscal and administrative incentives are introduced that incorporate climate resilient measures for small scale rural infrastructure (YES/NO). (AMAT 1.1.1.3)

baseline.comment: No fiscal and administrative incentives and structures are in place to promote climate resilient planning at sub-national level. The existing DDF mechanism has the ability to channel baseline development funding only.

target.comment: At least 25% in additional CCA funds (annual average) expended over and above baseline District Development Funding in at least 12 districts, based on a system that rewards districts that perform well against predetermined criteria.

actual.comment: A 2nd draft of the revised DDF guidelines has been produced based on experiences of implementing the first 4 pilot projects. The guidelines will be approved in 2nd half of 2015.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Natural assets (such as wetlands, forests and other ecosystems in sub-catchments) over at least 60,000 ha are managed to ensure maintenance of critical ecosystem services, especially water provisioning, flood control and protection under increasing climate change induced stresses, in Sekong and Saravane provinces.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 3.1 Number of management /action plans developed and under implementation, which protect natural assets through local scale ecosystems based adaptation measures to improve the resilience of small-scale rural infrastructure against floods and drought. (AMAT 1.2.1.9)

baseline.comment: Land use and management procedures and plans supporting climate change resilience of sub-catchments and small-scale rural infrastructures do not exist or if so are poorly implemented

target.comment: At least 6 management and action plans covering at least 48 climate resilience small-scale infrastructure investments under implementation across both Sekong and Saravane provinces.

actual.comment:
Two (2) road maps for development management plans for the two selected areas have been developed through extensive consultations with districts and provinces (January, February, March 2015). The starting point for the plans will be to undertake participatory land-use planning in the areas. This will be done through collaboration with Department of Land Planning and Development (DLPD) under MONRE, and their provincial and district units. DLPD has a national process of parallel "macro-level" and "micro-level" land-use planning processes going on, and has already undertaken macro-level land-use planning in Sekong (Thateng district, where where the Phu Ta Yeune ecosystem is situated). They still need to implement micro-level (i.e. village-based) land-use planning, so this offer a good opportunity for the project to link up to the existing national process, and insert climate change issues, including ecosystem-based adaptation as elements of the land-use planning process. Eventually, this offers good opportunities for up-scaling of area-based climate resilience planning, including ecosystem-based adaptation to the national level.
In terms of any additional ecosystem areas, these will be selected based on the needs of existing and new infrastructure projects in order to increase integration between Project Outcome 2 and 3.
The two existing ecosystem areas are both within the Sedone watershed. The other major watershed in the project, upper Sekong, will include a number of infrastructure projects in Kaleum, Dakchung and Lamarm districts, and ecosystem management for ecosystem-based adaptation is therefore needed in the upper Sekong watershed as well. Collaboration with the ADB-funded project Biodiversity Conservation Corridors Project (BCCP), which include the conservation and management of approximately 170,000 ha in the upper Sekong watershed in Kaleum and Dakchung districts, has been tentatively initiated. The project can build of activities already identified by BCCP, and incorporate watershed EbA measures that in turn will also benefit the BCCP. The collaboration with BCCP will be further detailed and formalised in Quarter 3 of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 3.2 Number of key project stakeholders aware of links between improved ecosystem management and sustainability of investments in small scale rural water infrastructure.

baseline.comment: Local planners and decision makers do not make the linkages between infrastructure investment and local land management practices. There is little or no information available to planners providing a reference point or practical experience in this area.

target.comment: At least 250 national, provincial and district planners have received knowledge and learning approaches and materials produced by the project on ecosystem based management linkages to infrastructure provision.

actual.comment: A Capacity Needs Assessment was carried out at local level (provinces and districts) in October 2015, based on which a capacity development plan was developed. This plan emphasises 'on-the-job' activities, i.e. capacity development activities that are linked to project implementation. This ensures a better 'uptake' compared with conventional training sessions. Training sessions targeting specific topics such as GIS, modelling etc. will still be considered. Approximately 150 local government staff have been involved with capacity development events, including members of DDST and DDSCs, as well as PONRE and DONRE officers.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Output 1: 1. Capacity development plan developed 2. At least 2 districts of the target provinces have completed Hazard Risk Vulnerability Assessments (HRVAs) 3. Clear mandate for integration of Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR) in the sectoral plans of DRR focal points developed 4. Disaster law developed 5. Post Disaster Needs Assessment (PDNA) developed 6. Early Recovery Cluster functioned with defined roles, responsibilities and contingency plan.
Output 2: 1. Coordination capacity of Department of Disaster Management and Climate Change (DDMCC) improved 2. Number of Disaster Management Information System established at the centre and local levels 3. Number of effective end to end user early warning system established in close coordination with the HMD, Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, MRC, WB/ADPC and based on the draft EWS strategy

actual.comment:

However, a study tour to Viet Nam was held to increase knowledge of Lao government officials in disaster legislation. 5. Input to PDNA was provided by UNDP and final PDNA is aimed to be finalized in 2015. 6. Yes

location.name: Laos
location.activity-description: This Project focuses on (1) lawmaking capacity of NA members and staff, (2) oversight role and institutional capacity of NA, and (3) people's participation in the decision making process. Main beneficiaries include NA members and staff, constituency offices at local level, and constituents in differ

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Output 1
Indicator 1: Percentage of new NA Members (first time MNAs) that demonstrate basic skills in law making and review [using the law making manual from SPLSMP].
Indicator 2: Number of legislative briefs prepared and submitted by NA staff to the NA Committees and Members
Indicator 3: Percentage of NA Committees and Members making reference to the gender and social inclusion guidelines of the Law Making manual in their work
Output 2
Indicator 1: Number of selected NA and NA Constituency Office (NACO) staff (in 4 pilot COs) that demonstrate basic skills on research, policy analysis, archiving and data gathering techniques
Indicator 2: Number of legislative briefs submitted to NA Members by pilot constituency offices
Indicator 3: Percentage of recommendations based on the NA Capacity Development Plan including strengthening of the ICPMS unit pilot-tested
Indicator 4: Level of progress made in developing the parliamentary database (NA intranet)
*Scale of Progress from 0 to 3 points: 0 = No existing NA intranet or database in place; 1 = NA intranet/parliamentary database established; 2 = NA intranet improved and updated with selected NA staff including NACOs trained; 3 = 18 NACOs have stable ICT connection and regularly utilized the intranet for their legislation work
Output 3
Indicator 1: (i) Number of issues raised by constituents during fact-finding missions and public consultations conducted by NA Committees (ii) Percentage of constituents expressing satisfaction for the information they received during pilot public information events or "constituency office days" in selected provinces.
Indicator 2: Percentage of recommendations in the public consultation guidelines pilot-tested by the NA Committees.
Indicator 3: Level of progress in the development of an NA-stakeholders roadmap or guidelines for NA engagement with mass organizations, disadvantaged groups, NPAs and INGOs.
* Scale of Progress from 0 to 3 points: 0 = No roadmap or guidelines

baseline.comment:
Output 1
Baseline 1: 0% [Law making manual is being finalized and translated into Lao]
Baseline 2: 0 [Members of the NA received information papers prior to NA session. These information papers only provided general information and comparative examples of laws from other countries]
Baseline 3: 0% [No guidelines or mechanism to review gender and social inclusion issues in draft bills and amendments to the laws]
Output 2
Baseline 1: 0 [Most research, analyses and information gathering functions are delegated to the NA Secretariat Department and NA Information Center. Most NACO staff have limited skills in research, analysis and data gathering]
Baseline 2: 0 [There are no existing legislative briefs prepared and submitted to NA Members by constituency offices]
Baseline 3: 0 [Capacity assessment of the NA Members and staff including constituency offices was conducted and draft report is still being reviewed by the NA]
Baseline 4: 1 [NA intranet/parliamentary database established]
Output 3
Baseline 1: (i) 0 [NA does not have record the number of issues raised by the constituents during fact finding missions and public consultations (ii) 0% [NA constituency offices have not organized public information events or open days]
Baseline 2: 0 [ Public consultation guidelines are being revised and to be submitted to the NA for approval]
Baseline 3: 0 [No existing NA-stakeholders' roadmap or guidelines for NA engagement with mass organizations, disadvantaged groups, NPAs and INGOs]
Sub-output 3.1 Baseline 3.1 (i): NA website had 1 million visitors in 2014. (ii): 2 draft bills and adopted laws discussed in the conduct of outreach missions and public consultations.
Sub-output 3.2 Baseline 3.2: 0 [No existing constituents reports prepared by the communities or citizens]
Sub-output 3.3 Baseline 3.3: 0% [In 2015, NA assessment on public engagement tools was conducted with recommendations on how to further improve them]
Sub-output 3.4 Baseline 3.4: 15% of the petit
